title: A journal of a residence ... in London; including excursions through various parts of England; and a short tour in France and Scotland; in the years 1823 and 1824
author: Wheaton, Nathaniel Sheldon.
snippet: Crossing the North Loch, the spectator finds himself in Prince's street, a noble terrace running from east to west along the margin ofthe Loch, above which it is elevated fifty or sixty feet. To the eastward, the Loch makes a turn to the north at the soot of Calton Hill, where it is crossed by Prince's Street, terminating in Regent Road, which winds around the southern base ofthe hill. Regent Bridge, extending across the Loch, is altogether a magnificent work.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: On leaving the palace, we take the North Breck of the Canongate a short distance, and turn to the right to have a look at Burns' monument on Regent Road. It is built in the style of a Greek peripteral temple, and contains a

title: The Red Room
author: Le Queux, William
snippet: Ten minutes later I was with the German hairdresser on a tram-car, going up Regent Road, towards Abbey Hill. On turning into the London Road at the station, we descended, and, crossing the main thoroughfare, entered one of the narrow, ill-lit turnings on the left, the name of which I was unable to see.

title: Bonnie Hills o'Hame, and other gems. [Verses.]
author: Scott, William
snippet: The Regent Road divides two conditions of life, namely, liberty and confinement. Within speaking distance from the hilltop the prisoners, clothed in their canvas suits, are seen patroUing the rings at exercise, with warders posted at intervals, who have them under observation so that any irregularities may be properly dealt with.

title: Four years in the Old world;
author: Palmer, Phoebe
snippet: A fine structure to the memory of the jjoet Burns is on the south side of the Regent Road. It stands on a rock about ten feet high.
